sin 1t may not be unin,erestng to some Of your
distant readers, to he informed of the manner Of
shooting Wild Ducks on the Susquehanna; and
though many OF them may be increduous, no cit
zen OF Cecil county will doubt The sequel.


The phrase TDleing Ducks is peculiar to this
patt OF the world, aud is not understood any where
else; and i, prac'ised in the following manner
When gunner discovers flock OF ducks floating
a, 100 gteai distance to be shot from the shore.
he crawls near to the water. and conceals himself
nehnd blind, which he previously erected for the
uur pose, o. logs coveted with syer grass He has
with him dog trained to run afer chips or small
stones the colo, Of the dog should be red or white.
hough almost every color has been found to answer
= times Concealed from the ducks, the gunner
throws stone the edge OF the water, end the
log Instantly springs from the blind and runs after
il. A the sight nt The dog playing on the shore,
he du ks stretch out their long eks and gaze with
apparent amazeoen, and curiosity, like gang Of
negroes At Punch in the puppet show. The gun
ner continues to throw stones right and left, and
The dog to run after them; the dog should be kept
unning as las, possible and not allowed to stop
If it can be avoided or an instant his large bushy
tail ought to be constantly in motion. The ducks
IT the meanwhile delighted with the singular
spectacle, and swim towards the dog fast their
feet can paddle them, great is their impatt nee
10 get nearer view OF him, that those which arc
iurthest off ill ny and light between bin and those
that were nearest All the time the ducks keep
,he ewes fixed upon the dog. and seem TO be gov
ened by spell which they have not power nor IN
clination 10 break, like birds charmed by a black
snake. As soon as the gunner perceiycs that the
ducks take notice Of his dog, his hope is raised fre-
quenty TO be disappointed, for il the ducks see the
gunner, or il his dog run behind any thing on the
shore that conceal, him from their sight. or if from
fatigue or aziness he decline running, it he bark
or lie down TO gnaw the stone that was thrown tor
him, which frequently happens, instantly the spell is
broken, and the dacks take TO their wings. II
however, no accident happens. and every thing
works right, Gas the duckers say) often flock o
ducks that cover half OF water, is toled as I
: were by magic, from Goo yards OF upwards TO with


in twenty eet of the gunner. The numbers ina
are killed in this way, incredible. for there arr
gene ray two three gunners that shoot from the
same blind will not attempt TO account Tor toieine
ducks; by what instinct impulse they are rulet
il coming TO the dog, whether il be curiosity OF
magic, know not but know that the tact exists
as have stated, and can be altested by hondreds
gunners on the Susqueh hanna and defy Dr. Mitch
ell or any other sage, TO give satisfactory explana
J. tion of il. have seen the same flock OF duck
toled 10 the shore three times in one day by tht
. SAME dog, and shot at each time. |. is not to b


supposed that the dog is conscious oi the effect III


produces on the ducks, or knows that they come le
he shore TO see him: he is engaged playing Will
the stones that are thrown for him, and thinks o
: ohne else. There is difficulty in training toler


most dogs are too lazy. and refuse to run as sooI
DUCK SHOOTING.

By lie Reu. r.. Dale.
o, breathe no more that simple air,
Though soft and sweet thy wild notes swell,
To me the only tale they tell


Is cold despair
| heard It once from lips as fair,
Iheald It 10 AS sweet a tone,-
Nos am left on earth alone,


And she s-ahere'
How have those w-il.known sounds renewed
The dealos Of earlier, happier hours,
When lie, desert now, was stfewed


With fairy howcrs:--
Then III MAS hright, and fond, and fair,
Nov flowers arc faded, joys are fed,
And heart and hope are with the dead,


For she is-uhete'
Can then love the air she loved
Cav, tiien hear the melting strain
Which brings her to my soul a., ain


Calm aud unmoved
And ihou 10 blame my tears forbear;
For while list, sweet maid to thee.
Remembrance whispers, .such Was she,'


Aud she is-alierel

ny DeFittVu BurtOH.
Gin the morning it hourisheth, and groweth up
e evening i Is cut down, and withcreth "-Psal xc.
walk'd the fields at mornings prime,
The grass was ripe for moving;
The sky-ark sang his inan chime,
Aud all vas brightly glowing
Sand thus" cried, :" the ardent boy,
HIS pulse with rapture beating,
Deems Llfe's Inheritance is joy
The future proudly greeting"
wandered forth at noon alas.
On carh's maternal bosom
The cythe had left the whitening grass
And slretcl'd the fading blossom.
And thus, thought with many sigh,
The hopes we fondy cherish,
Like flowers which blossom but to die
Seem only born TO perish.
Once more, al eve, abroad stray'd,
Through lonely hay fields musing;
While every breeze that round INC playd
Rich fragrance was ditiusng.
The perfumed air, the hush of eve,
10 purer hopes appealing
O'er thoughts Perchance too prone o greYc,
Scaltcrd the balm of healing.
For lhns the actions of the JUST
When Memory hath enshrined them,
Fen from the dark and silent dust
Their ordour leave behind them.
HUMAN LIFE.
Dy Beriiard barton.

as their feet get cut by the stones and shells on The
shore, and few OF them will play alter they have
frequently the ducks shot, but sop 10 look at
them when they approach the shore and sometimes
plunge into the water after them before they are
near enough TO be killed. gunner should be
provided with several dogs to bring the ducks he
shoots out Ut the water and suffer his tolsr
do it, lest he contract the habit of neglecng his
play to swim after the ducks before they are shot
The Newfoundland breed make the best water dogs
and plunge into the most rapid stream or break
through the ice in the coldcst weather to bring out
ducks. Ducks are not TO be toled at all times, nor
the same flock very often, and there are several
kinds that will ,ole Early in the season that
is, the latter part Of October or first Of November,
the canvass back and red-head, the most delicious
of all fea,hered toe 10 abundance, but after
being shot at several times they become wild, and
will fly at the sight OF dog. Some Of the Susque.
hanna gunners can ascertain nine times out OF ten,
without making the experiment, by watching the
motions OF flo, o. ducks, whether they are in the
notion OF oleing, will fly from the dog. This is
the last art that gunner acquires and Is not 10 be
learned except from experience. No state in the
Union abounds with water fowl Of every description
equally with The land nf Mary. They are to be
found 10 the bay below Hayre-de Grace, numerous
enough to da ken the air, and the thunder Of their
wings Can be heard when they rise from the water,
al the distance OF ten miles, The art al tolcng,
ike many other curious arts, was discovered by
accidents and tradition says that gunner concealed
behind blind, watching 1nck ot ducks, presently
saw fox playing on the shore, and was prised
70 perceive the ducks swimming to shore to gaze at
him; il he ran up the beach, they swan in that di
reclion and gazed at him in silent admiration; or
i he down the beach, they followed, approaching
as near as they could without leaving the water.
ReyEard though proyerbialy cunning, had no de
sign upon the ducks, he was rolling and pranclng
tor amusement; but the gunner took the hint, and
after shooting great number Of ducks that The fox.
without intending, had oled for him, he started his
d4g to running on the shote. by throwing pieces Of
bread for him, and TO hi. great delight, discovered
that the project succeeded.


The Chesapeake Bay and its tributary streams
! supply every city in the Union with ducks, swans,
and geese and sometimes they are exported TO
London. Here to be found an army OF the me 81
unerring marksmcn in the world, consisting ri gen,
lemeD who shoot for pleasure, as we'll as gunnets
who shoo' ducks for sale have not time to speak
Of the mode OF shooting ducks the wing, p.ac-
tised in this state. A SPORTSMAN.
enry Wilson, No. 1Oo, Market Street.

and The keeper dragged the other to bis cage and Sc
cured them both. Aud thus, by singular train OF
circumstances, in which the instinct and trunk OF


the elephant, no less ,han the teeth and temper of
the lion bore conspic ecus part did tile poor keep
er get rescued from the Jaws Of the tiger and til
gress; and the whole affair has been the table talk
OF the Bowery for he last week.

NOTICE.

OPENING OF TIE NEW PARLIAMENT By HIS


MAJESTY IN PERSON.
We stated yesterday, that the Kins had sign6etl
his gracious intention of delivering personally from
the throne, the Royal Speech, declaringihe purpo-
ses for which the two HOUSES Of Palisuent had
been called together. Accordingly. every 7repara-
tion made for his Majesty's reception, and up
wards OF fifty workmeD were employed Yesterday
and last night in cleaning the stair new Gall
leries, and Painted Chamber, an6 along which his
Majesty has TO pass from and TO his carriage


II being known that The splendid ceremony would
take place, at an early hour crowds OF persons be-
gan to collect in the opening spac. adjoining the
House, and by twelve O'Clock every accessible spot
WAS occupied. The Inc Of road from the House.
along Parliament street, Charingcioss. aud Pail
Mail, 10 ST. Jsmes's Palace, was crowded with spec
tatots who received his Majesty with loud and rslt-
Grated cheers. 1t is impossible to imagine recep-
lion expressive of loyalty and attachment
His Majesty we are happy to -sy, appeared in ex-
cellrnt health, and knowedged ltom lnie 10 time
the enthusiastic pauds OF his subjects
! The House OF Lords, the Painted Chamher, the
new Gallery sc. were csnadtG with company soon
after twelve o'clock. We have seldom seen the
Peeresses, and their daughters, or those admitted
by Peers orders into the body OF the House, dlspay
a more elegant sppearance


/ Al ten minutes before two the King arrived ae
4 The House. and len minutes - Two, having rob-
ed, his Majesty entered, and took his seat upon the
Throne. The House Of Commons were then sum
moned to the bar, in the usual form, by the Usher
of the Black Rod, and having taken their station,
with the Speaker at their head, his Majesty deliver
ed the following Speech in an audible tone =


".Ny Lords and Gentlemen,


81 have called you together at this time Tor the
special purpose Of communicating 10 you The mea-
sure, which judged it necessary TO take in the
month OF September, Tor the admission into the
perts OF th- United KIM dom o! certain sorts Of
Foreign Grain. not then admissible by law.
9 have directed copy oi the order in Council
issued cn that occasion 10 be laid besore you and
confidently ,rust that you will sufi cient reason


for giving your SANCTION to The provisions of that
Order, and Tor carrying them into ei!ectual exeeu-
ton.


II have great satisfaction in being able TO inform
you, that The hopes entertained the close Of the
last Session OF Parliament. respecting the tersnina-
lion Of the war in the Burn Territories, have
been fulfilled and that peace has been concluded


in hat quarter, highly honorable to the British Gov
eminent in India.


:" continue TO receive from a Foreign Powers
assurances OF ;heir earnest desire cultivate the
relations ct peace and friendly understanding.
:" am eSerting myself with unremit'ing anxiety,
whether singly in conjunction with my allies, as
well to airest the progress OF existing hosil.ies, as
to prevent The interruption Of peace in the different
parts of the world.


/" Gentlemen of the House Of Commons-


IL have directed The estimates for The ensuing


year bs prepared, and they will, IN due time be


laid before you


II will take care that they shall be formed with
Us much attention TO economy as the exgencies OF
) the public service will permit.
"The distress which has pervaded the commcr.
cial and manufacturing classes ol my subjects dur
ing the last twelve months, has affected some I'M


portant branches OF the Revenue. But have the
satisfaction Of informing you that there has been
no such diminution in the internal consumption OF
the country to excite any appIehens'ens thai the
great sources of our wealth and prosperity nave
been impaired.


s..Ny Lords and Gentlemen.
5 81 have deeply sympahsed With the suHerings
which have been for souc lime past so severely


felt in the manufacturing districts oi the country.
IL have conte mplated, with great satisfaction,


the exemplary patience with WHICH those sutferings
have been borne.


/, ..The depression under which The trade and
) manufactures of the country have been aborng has
5 abaied mole slowly than had thought myself war
ranled in anticipating But retain hi m exptca-
ton that this abatement will be progressive and mat
The time is not distant when uncsr The blessing or
; Divine Providence. the commerce and Industry OF
the United King dom viii have resumed their won't
! ed activity


/ + Old Bachelors MIR Reneau introduced bill lin
the legislature OF Tennessee by which was made


the duty oil the Sheriff Of each county, 10 make an
annual return of every man who shall have attained
the age OF Thirty without marryng; aud also OF an
his property, which tax Of 25 per cent is 10 De
laid ard the fund lh,rehy created, by he provisions
OF the bill, is be divided among such upmai leo


ladies have reached The age OF twenty-five. ! ne


bill further provides, that il any old bachelor suffers


himself to be returned three times, he shall thence
forth he deemed incorrigibe, and The tax Increased


to fifty per cent. The bill passed with great unan-

An extraordinary instance Of animal saeacfy and
Of personal preservation by means of it, is mention
ed in the New York National Advocate. AT
small circus in the Bowery. in which is an exhiLl


of wild beasts such eiephants lions, tigers. SC.
whilst the keeper was al dinner, tiger and tigrsss
broke from their cage, which diap:daed
state ,and immediately seized upon defenceless Ia
ma. They were enjoying their repa,t when the
keeper entered Although alarmed at first, he re
suned sufficient courage tsays the Advocate) oven
ture into the ring with moose to fling over the
heads OF the two Ierocious animals while they were
sucking out the last drop OF blood from the poor la
ma. The tiGress Flushing her repast sooner than
her male, turned round while the keeper was in the
very act of catching them and made preparations TO
spring upon him. The keeper felt the danger OF
his situation, but with great presence o mind, made
retreat behind his elephant, who from the other
side OF the circus, looking on the with
great composure. The tigress did not forego her
intent. She made spring at the keeper past the
elephant; but just at this moment, the sagaeious
animal Observing il would seem. the danger of his
keeper, lie. nul his trunk with the velocity Of an


row from the bow, and pitched the lisress to the
farther end OF The circus. A wonderful hurley
ley was kicked Up. All the mOnkies and ba-
boons scampered up to the raiters and The glarng
eys of The enraged 'igress struck dread into The
whole, except the elephant, who folded up his trunk
with ncatness alter his feat, and the lion, who sat IN
his cage on his lips like dog looking OH with great


dignity and composure. The keeper now ran out


from behind the elephant, and approaching his
trunk, uttered ceriain words, which the sasacious
anima understands with so much correctness The
elephant unrolied his trunk the keeper got astrlde


and in moment was elevated TO the back oi
his preserver. In the meantime the tgress had re-
4 covered from the toss she had got, and made new
preparations TO spring upon the keeper, who was
upon the back oi the elephant. Again the igress
sprang upon the man, and again the elephant inter
terposed his trunk and tossed the tig,ess second
time TO the far'hest extremity of the circus. This
pitch wounded The side OF the igress. and finding
there no use in trying further to tap The juguas
Of the keeper, she sneaked away into her cage with
what she had got. While this business was going
on, the tiger himself had begun to look round. On
raising hi. head from the lama, the first thing that


struck him the lion sitting in his cage with great


dignity and unconcern. The tiger showed his teeth !;
the lion slightly shook his name. he tiger drew
back on his hind legs to make spring the lion
rose up with dignity and shot fire from his eyes. The
tiger sprang al the cage with great fury, forcing
one OF his claws 10 between two Of the bars; and at
the same instant the lion seized the tigers fore foot
caugh. it firmly between his tusks, pulled the whole


leg into the cage and held him there until the keep


er, seeing the opportunity, flung himself from the
back OF the elephant, ran with his moose to the Il
ger and secured him in moment. After this was
accomplished, the lion generously let go his hold

sin 1t may not be unin,erestng to some Of your

he crawls near to the water. and conceals himself

hough almost every color has been found to answer

full articles.article:
By lie Reu. r.. Dale.
o, breathe no more that simple air,
Though soft and sweet thy wild notes swell,
To me the only tale they tell


Is cold despair
| heard It once from lips as fair,
Iheald It 10 AS sweet a tone,-
Nos am left on earth alone,


And she s-ahere'
How have those w-il.known sounds renewed
The dealos Of earlier, happier hours,
When lie, desert now, was stfewed


With fairy howcrs:--
Then III MAS hright, and fond, and fair,
Nov flowers arc faded, joys are fed,
And heart and hope are with the dead,


For she is-uhete'
Can then love the air she loved
Cav, tiien hear the melting strain
Which brings her to my soul a., ain


Calm aud unmoved
And ihou 10 blame my tears forbear;
For while list, sweet maid to thee.
Remembrance whispers, .such Was she,'


Aud she is-alierel

full articles.headline: HUMAN LIFE.
full articles.article:
ny DeFittVu BurtOH.
Gin the morning it hourisheth, and groweth up
e evening i Is cut down, and withcreth "-Psal xc.
walk'd the fields at mornings prime,
The grass was ripe for moving;
The sky-ark sang his inan chime,
Aud all vas brightly glowing
Sand thus" cried, :" the ardent boy,
HIS pulse with rapture beating,
Deems Llfe's Inheritance is joy
The future proudly greeting"
wandered forth at noon alas.
On carh's maternal bosom
The cythe had left the whitening grass
And slretcl'd the fading blossom.
And thus, thought with many sigh,
The hopes we fondy cherish,
Like flowers which blossom but to die
Seem only born TO perish.
Once more, al eve, abroad stray'd,
Through lonely hay fields musing;
While every breeze that round INC playd
Rich fragrance was ditiusng.
The perfumed air, the hush of eve,
10 purer hopes appealing
O'er thoughts Perchance too prone o greYc,
Scaltcrd the balm of healing.
For lhns the actions of the JUST
When Memory hath enshrined them,
Fen from the dark and silent dust
Their ordour leave behind them.

full articles.article:
as their feet get cut by the stones and shells on The
shore, and few OF them will play alter they have
frequently the ducks shot, but sop 10 look at
them when they approach the shore and sometimes
plunge into the water after them before they are
near enough TO be killed. gunner should be
provided with several dogs to bring the ducks he
shoots out Ut the water and suffer his tolsr
do it, lest he contract the habit of neglecng his
play to swim after the ducks before they are shot
The Newfoundland breed make the best water dogs
and plunge into the most rapid stream or break
through the ice in the coldcst weather to bring out
ducks. Ducks are not TO be toled at all times, nor
the same flock very often, and there are several
kinds that will ,ole Early in the season that
is, the latter part Of October or first Of November,
the canvass back and red-head, the most delicious
of all fea,hered toe 10 abundance, but after
being shot at several times they become wild, and
will fly at the sight OF dog. Some Of the Susque.
hanna gunners can ascertain nine times out OF ten,
without making the experiment, by watching the
motions OF flo, o. ducks, whether they are in the
notion OF oleing, will fly from the dog. This is
the last art that gunner acquires and Is not 10 be
learned except from experience. No state in the
Union abounds with water fowl Of every description
equally with The land nf Mary. They are to be
found 10 the bay below Hayre-de Grace, numerous
enough to da ken the air, and the thunder Of their
wings Can be heard when they rise from the water,
al the distance OF ten miles, The art al tolcng,
ike many other curious arts, was discovered by
accidents and tradition says that gunner concealed
behind blind, watching 1nck ot ducks, presently
saw fox playing on the shore, and was prised
70 perceive the ducks swimming to shore to gaze at
him; il he ran up the beach, they swan in that di
reclion and gazed at him in silent admiration; or
i he down the beach, they followed, approaching
as near as they could without leaving the water.
ReyEard though proyerbialy cunning, had no de
sign upon the ducks, he was rolling and pranclng
tor amusement; but the gunner took the hint, and
after shooting great number Of ducks that The fox.
without intending, had oled for him, he started his
d4g to running on the shote. by throwing pieces Of
bread for him, and TO hi. great delight, discovered
that the project succeeded.


The Chesapeake Bay and its tributary streams
! supply every city in the Union with ducks, swans,
and geese and sometimes they are exported TO
London. Here to be found an army OF the me 81
unerring marksmcn in the world, consisting ri gen,
lemeD who shoot for pleasure, as we'll as gunnets
who shoo' ducks for sale have not time to speak
Of the mode OF shooting ducks the wing, p.ac-
tised in this state. A SPORTSMAN.

and The keeper dragged the other to bis cage and Sc
cured them both. Aud thus, by singular train OF
circumstances, in which the instinct and trunk OF


the elephant, no less ,han the teeth and temper of
the lion bore conspic ecus part did tile poor keep
er get rescued from the Jaws Of the tiger and til
gress; and the whole affair has been the table talk
OF the Bowery for he last week.

. 10000 -

From the London Courier ot .N'orember 81.
OPENING OF TlE NFW pARIftNENT nv HIS
full articles.article:
OPENING OF TIE NEW PARLIAMENT By HIS


MAJESTY IN PERSON.
We stated yesterday, that the Kins had sign6etl
his gracious intention of delivering personally from
the throne, the Royal Speech, declaringihe purpo-
ses for which the two HOUSES Of Palisuent had
been called together. Accordingly. every 7repara-
tion made for his Majesty's reception, and up
wards OF fifty workmeD were employed Yesterday
and last night in cleaning the stair new Gall
leries, and Painted Chamber, an6 along which his
Majesty has TO pass from and TO his carriage


II being known that The splendid ceremony would
take place, at an early hour crowds OF persons be-
gan to collect in the opening spac. adjoining the
House, and by twelve O'Clock every accessible spot
WAS occupied. The Inc Of road from the House.
along Parliament street, Charingcioss. aud Pail
Mail, 10 ST. Jsmes's Palace, was crowded with spec
tatots who received his Majesty with loud and rslt-
Grated cheers. 1t is impossible to imagine recep-
lion expressive of loyalty and attachment
His Majesty we are happy to -sy, appeared in ex-
cellrnt health, and knowedged ltom lnie 10 time
the enthusiastic pauds OF his subjects
! The House OF Lords, the Painted Chamher, the
new Gallery sc. were csnadtG with company soon
after twelve o'clock. We have seldom seen the
Peeresses, and their daughters, or those admitted
by Peers orders into the body OF the House, dlspay
a more elegant sppearance


/ Al ten minutes before two the King arrived ae
4 The House. and len minutes - Two, having rob-
ed, his Majesty entered, and took his seat upon the
Throne. The House Of Commons were then sum
moned to the bar, in the usual form, by the Usher
of the Black Rod, and having taken their station,
with the Speaker at their head, his Majesty deliver
ed the following Speech in an audible tone =


".Ny Lords and Gentlemen,


81 have called you together at this time Tor the
special purpose Of communicating 10 you The mea-
sure, which judged it necessary TO take in the
month OF September, Tor the admission into the
perts OF th- United KIM dom o! certain sorts Of
Foreign Grain. not then admissible by law.
9 have directed copy oi the order in Council
issued cn that occasion 10 be laid besore you and
confidently ,rust that you will sufi cient reason


for giving your SANCTION to The provisions of that
Order, and Tor carrying them into ei!ectual exeeu-
ton.


II have great satisfaction in being able TO inform
you, that The hopes entertained the close Of the
last Session OF Parliament. respecting the tersnina-
lion Of the war in the Burn Territories, have
been fulfilled and that peace has been concluded


in hat quarter, highly honorable to the British Gov
eminent in India.


:" continue TO receive from a Foreign Powers
assurances OF ;heir earnest desire cultivate the
relations ct peace and friendly understanding.
:" am eSerting myself with unremit'ing anxiety,
whether singly in conjunction with my allies, as
well to airest the progress OF existing hosil.ies, as
to prevent The interruption Of peace in the different
parts of the world.


/" Gentlemen of the House Of Commons-


IL have directed The estimates for The ensuing


year bs prepared, and they will, IN due time be


laid before you


II will take care that they shall be formed with
Us much attention TO economy as the exgencies OF
) the public service will permit.
"The distress which has pervaded the commcr.
cial and manufacturing classes ol my subjects dur
ing the last twelve months, has affected some I'M


portant branches OF the Revenue. But have the
satisfaction Of informing you that there has been
no such diminution in the internal consumption OF
the country to excite any appIehens'ens thai the
great sources of our wealth and prosperity nave
been impaired.


s..Ny Lords and Gentlemen.
5 81 have deeply sympahsed With the suHerings
which have been for souc lime past so severely


felt in the manufacturing districts oi the country.
IL have conte mplated, with great satisfaction,


the exemplary patience with WHICH those sutferings
have been borne.


/, ..The depression under which The trade and
) manufactures of the country have been aborng has
5 abaied mole slowly than had thought myself war
ranled in anticipating But retain hi m exptca-
ton that this abatement will be progressive and mat
The time is not distant when uncsr The blessing or
; Divine Providence. the commerce and Industry OF
the United King dom viii have resumed their won't
! ed activity


/ + Old Bachelors MIR Reneau introduced bill lin
the legislature OF Tennessee by which was made


the duty oil the Sheriff Of each county, 10 make an
annual return of every man who shall have attained
the age OF Thirty without marryng; aud also OF an
his property, which tax Of 25 per cent is 10 De
laid ard the fund lh,rehy created, by he provisions
OF the bill, is be divided among such upmai leo


ladies have reached The age OF twenty-five. ! ne


bill further provides, that il any old bachelor suffers


himself to be returned three times, he shall thence
forth he deemed incorrigibe, and The tax Increased


to fifty per cent. The bill passed with great unan-

full articles.article:
An extraordinary instance Of animal saeacfy and
Of personal preservation by means of it, is mention
ed in the New York National Advocate. AT
small circus in the Bowery. in which is an exhiLl


of wild beasts such eiephants lions, tigers. SC.
whilst the keeper was al dinner, tiger and tigrsss
broke from their cage, which diap:daed
state ,and immediately seized upon defenceless Ia
ma. They were enjoying their repa,t when the
keeper entered Although alarmed at first, he re
suned sufficient courage tsays the Advocate) oven
ture into the ring with moose to fling over the
heads OF the two Ierocious animals while they were
sucking out the last drop OF blood from the poor la
ma. The tiGress Flushing her repast sooner than
her male, turned round while the keeper was in the
very act of catching them and made preparations TO
spring upon him. The keeper felt the danger OF
his situation, but with great presence o mind, made
retreat behind his elephant, who from the other
side OF the circus, looking on the with
great composure. The tigress did not forego her
intent. She made spring at the keeper past the
elephant; but just at this moment, the sagaeious
animal Observing il would seem. the danger of his
keeper, lie. nul his trunk with the velocity Of an


row from the bow, and pitched the lisress to the
farther end OF The circus. A wonderful hurley
ley was kicked Up. All the mOnkies and ba-
boons scampered up to the raiters and The glarng
eys of The enraged 'igress struck dread into The
whole, except the elephant, who folded up his trunk
with ncatness alter his feat, and the lion, who sat IN
his cage on his lips like dog looking OH with great


dignity and composure. The keeper now ran out


from behind the elephant, and approaching his
trunk, uttered ceriain words, which the sasacious
anima understands with so much correctness The
elephant unrolied his trunk the keeper got astrlde


and in moment was elevated TO the back oi
his preserver. In the meantime the tgress had re-
4 covered from the toss she had got, and made new
preparations TO spring upon the keeper, who was
upon the back oi the elephant. Again the igress
sprang upon the man, and again the elephant inter
terposed his trunk and tossed the tig,ess second
time TO the far'hest extremity of the circus. This
pitch wounded The side OF the igress. and finding
there no use in trying further to tap The juguas
Of the keeper, she sneaked away into her cage with
what she had got. While this business was going
on, the tiger himself had begun to look round. On
raising hi. head from the lama, the first thing that


struck him the lion sitting in his cage with great


dignity and unconcern. The tiger showed his teeth !;
the lion slightly shook his name. he tiger drew
back on his hind legs to make spring the lion
rose up with dignity and shot fire from his eyes. The
tiger sprang al the cage with great fury, forcing
one OF his claws 10 between two Of the bars; and at
the same instant the lion seized the tigers fore foot
caugh. it firmly between his tusks, pulled the whole


leg into the cage and held him there until the keep


er, seeing the opportunity, flung himself from the
back OF the elephant, ran with his moose to the Il
ger and secured him in moment. After this was
accomplished, the lion generously let go his hold
